hard.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: firm, stiff, and difficult to press down, break, or cut
hard.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: the hardest substance known to man
After months without rain, the ground was too hard to plough.
hard.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: This year’s exam was much harder than last year’s.
You’ll have to make some hard decisions.
They’re a hard team to beat.
Permanent jobs are hard to come by (=difficult to find or get).
Telling my parents is going to be the hardest thing about it.
Such criticism was hard to take (=difficult to accept).
It was hard to see what else we could have done.
it is hard to believe/imagine/see/know etc
It’s hard to believe that anyone would say something like that.
it is hard to believe/imagine/see/know etc
I was finding it hard to concentrate.
find it hard to do something
You’ll have a hard time proving that.
have a hard time doing something
I had a hard time persuading him to accept the offer.
have a hard time doing something
It must be hard for her, bringing up three kids on her own.
hard.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: using or involving a lot of mental or physical effort
hard.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: To be successful in sport requires hard work and a great deal of determination.
After a hard day at work, I just want to come home and put my feet up.
Becoming a doctor never interested him. It was too much like hard work (=it would involve too much work).
There’s a sauna where you can relax after a hard day’s skiing.
hard.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a situation or time that is hard is one in which you have a lot of problems, especially when you do not have enough money
hard.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Times were hard and they were forced to sell their house.
He had clearly fallen on hard times (=did not have much money).
hard.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Jane gave the door a good hard push.
She gave him a hard slap.
hard.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: showing no sympathetic or gentle feelings
hard.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Her voice was hard and cold.
hard.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: hard water contains a lot of minerals, and does not mix easily with soap
hard.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: strong, ready to fight, and not afraid of anyone or anything
hard.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Jones was known as soccer’s hard man.
hard.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: hard light is bright and unpleasant
hard.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: the hard brilliance of the moonlight
hard.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: I never touch the hard stuff (=strong alcohol).
hard.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: a hard ‘c’ is pronounced /k/ rather than /s/; a hard ‘g’ is pronounced /g/ rather than /dz/
hard.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: difficult to press down, break, or cut, and not at all soft
I fell onto the hard stone floor.
The clay gets harder as it dries.
firm
not completely hard, but not easy to press or bend – used especially when this seems a good thing
I like to sleep on a firm mattress.
exercises to make your stomach muscles nice and firm
The pears were firm and juicy.
stiff
difficult to bend and not changing shape
a piece of stiff cardboard
The collar of his shirt felt stiff and uncomfortable.
solid
made of a thick hard material and not hollow
a solid oak door
The floor felt strong and solid beneath her feet.
rigid
having a structure that is made of a material that is difficult or impossible to bend
The tent is supported by a rigid frame.
Carry sandwiches in a rigid container.
crisp/crispy
used about food that is pleasantly hard, so that it makes a noise when you bite it – often used about things that have been cooked in thin slices until they are brown
Bake the cookies until they are crisp and golden.
crispy bacon
crunchy
food that is crunchy makes a noise when you bite on it – often used about things that are fresh, for example fruit, vegetables, and nuts
a crunchy breakfast cereal
The carrots were still nice and crunchy.
a crunchy salad
crunchy peanut butter
meat that is tough is too hard and is difficult to cut or eat
The meat was tough and flavourless.
rubbery
too hard and bending like rubber rather than breaking – used especially about meat
The chicken was all rubbery.
hard.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: using a lot of effort, energy, or attention
hard.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: She has worked hard all her life.
He had thought long and hard before getting involved with the project.
She tried her hardest to ignore what he’d said.
I couldn’t convince him no matter how hard I tried.
hard.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: You need to hit the ball hard.
He slammed the door hard behind him.
hard.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: By now the cement had set hard.
hard.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: information based on things that can be measured, rather than feelings or opinions
hard.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Investors are again showing respect for hard numbers like quarterly earnings.
We have to separate the myths from the hard facts.
hard.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: a hard market is one in which there is less competition and higher prices or rates
hard.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: To be successful in a hard market, producers must devote more time than ever to cultivating relationships with clients.
